overview_of_class:
Prof. Galya Ruffer "Critical Perspectives on Human Rights" Winter 2017
Human rights have become the dominant frame for thinking about social justice and the path to human rights is paved with written documentation of human rights abuses and testimony. How do we know what we know about human rights abuses? In this course students will consider the relationship between the documentation of human rights abuses and justice. In our examination we will question: on what does the will to address human rights depend? And, how do the international narratives that emerge of human rights abuses relate to the victims and survivors of those abuses? Students will be introduced to the international human rights framework and then focus on the practice of human rights through case studies on the prosecution of sexual violence in international courts, the advocacy campaign to end the warehousing of refugees in camps and the struggle to recognize FGM as a form of persecution. We will question the received wisdom about the role of human rights in struggles for justice and learn about tensions between human rights and national sovereignty, the role of advocacy groups and the challenges of localizing human rights. Students will be introduced to the methodologies and tools of human rights documentation and consider the challenges of thinking as a human rights advocate. Based on our study of research and writing about rights, students will develop and share their own research projects.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. Provide students an overview of the international human rights organizational structure and legal framework of reporting violations;
2. Introduce students to the evidentiary questions and concerns of human rights documentation and research techniques of documenting human rights abuses;
3. Critically examine power relations in knowledge production and epistemological differences in what constitutes knowledge and the value attached to knowledge.
4. To be introduced to the methodology and tools of human rights documentation, practice interview techniques and simulate an investigation
5. To gain understanding regarding the challenges of human rights advocacy.
6. Convey to students the ethical responsibility of research and documentation
7. Read and critically engage with a variety of primary and secondary sources about human rights, including identifying an author's point of view and main argument and assessing its credibility and persuasiveness ?
8. Apply insights from critical reading to developing and researching a human rights ?question and sharing your research in written and oral form ?

overview_of_class:
The Unequal Global Political Economy, Prof. Moses Khisa, Winter 2017
The globe is diverse, varied, and complex. But it is also highly unequal and uneven. Scholarly debates have focused mainly on global economic inequality. But there is gross political inequality too, in the regimes and institutions that govern transnational relations, in military capabilities, and in the political influences that nation-states and non-state actors wield. There are extreme inequalities in the global distribution of material resources and wealth, but there is equally wide disparities in the concentration of particularly influential ideas and political practices between the global North and the South.
In this research and writing seminar, we will take up this topical and critical aspect of the global political economy and interrogate its wide-ranging causes and consequences. The first part of this seminar will survey key domains of material and political inequality, including disparities in national and cross-national income, production output, supranational organizations and global governance institutions, trade and financial flows, multilateral agreements, among others. The second part of the seminar will cover some of the major consequences of global political and economic inequality: poverty and human development, borrowing and indebtedness, global order and instability, etc.

overview_of_class:
The Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Prof. Wendy Pearlman Winter 2017
This course explores the history and politics of the Israeli- Palestinian conflict. We will study the conflict's development from its origins until the present, as well as a range of perspectives on topics such as the sources of violence, the rise and fall of the peace process, United States policy toward the conflict, and the nature of internal politics for both Israelis and Palestinians. The course is divided into two parts, the first focusing on understanding history and the second on analyzing politics.

overview_of_class:
Civilians in war, Prof. Ana Arjona Winter 2017
This seminar explores the behavior of civilians in contexts of civil war. Why do they join one of the warring sides, including rebels, paramilitaries or regular armies? Why do they resist against the presence of these groups in their territory? Why do they support rebels or incumbents? Why do they leave their hometowns to become refugees or internally displaced? How do they change their decisions regarding economic activities, social relations, and family dynamics? We approach these questions through both theoretical and empirical pieces (including case studies, comparative analyses, and human rights reports).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
(i) Students will acquire a critical understanding of the situation of civilians in contexts of war as well as their choices.
(ii) Students will acquire a critical understanding of the dynamics of civil war.
(iii) Students will improve their analytical skills for studying political and social phenomena. In particular, they will improve their capacity to evaluate statements about causality.
(iv) Students will improve their analytical skills for studying public policy. In particular, they will improve their capacity to evaluate normative and positive statements and the links between them.
